title: Question 61

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for an episode of aphasia and right-sided weakness that occurred 7 hours ago and lasted 3 hours. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia treated with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin and low-dose aspirin.

All physical examination findings, including vital signs, are unremarkable. Head CT, ECG, prolonged telemetry monitoring, and echocardiogram are all normal. CT angiogram shows 70% stenosis of the left internal carotid artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to reduce this patient's risk for stroke?
Carotid endarterectomy for critical carotid artery stenosis is highly effective in reducing the risk for recurrent stroke in the immediate poststroke period.

With symptomatic carotid stenosis, the risk for recurrent stroke is 1% per day for the first 2 weeks after a stroke or TIA; therefore, the greatest benefit of carotid endarterectomy is gained when the procedure is performed early.
This patient should be referred for urgent endarterectomy of the left internal carotid artery (
Option A

). He has had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) consisting of aphasia and right-sided weakness due to symptomatic high-grade carotid stenosis. The risk for recurrent stroke is approximately 26% over the next 2 years. Carotid endarterectomy is highly effective in reducing the risk for recurrent stroke in the immediate poststroke period. With symptomatic carotid stenosis, the risk for recurrent stroke is 1% per day for the first 2 weeks after a stroke or TIA; therefore, the greatest benefit is gained when the procedure is performed early.
Carotid stenting (
Option B

) would be inappropriate for this patient. Clinical trials have shown that for the outcomes of stroke, myocardial infarction, and death, stenting and endarterectomy are not significantly different. However, stenting poses a greater risk for perioperative stroke than does endarterectomy. Therefore, it is not recommended as a primary intervention for symptomatic carotid artery stenosis. In patients who are considered high risk for carotid endarterectomy, such as those with major cardiac comorbid conditions, stenting is an alternative.
Prasugrel (
Option C
) is a P2Y

receptor blocker used as an antiplatelet agent. Prasugrel may cause significant, sometimes fatal, bleeding. It is contraindicated in patients with active pathological bleeding or a history of TIA or stroke. Clopidogrel, another P2Y

agent, has a role in medical therapy for patients who cannot take aspirin. However, antiplatelet agents generally provide only a marginal benefit compared with surgery in reducing the risk for stroke in the acute period after a stroke or TIA caused by symptomatic high-grade carotid stenosis.

Anticoagulation in the context of acute stroke has been associated with increased mortality rates and poorer neurologic outcomes. Long-term anticoagulation with a direct-acting anticoagulant, such as rivaroxaban (
Option D

) or warfarin, is beneficial only in patients whose stroke is caused by atrial fibrillation or another source of cardiogenic embolism. Because this patient's stroke probably resulted from his high-grade carotid stenosis, treatment with rivaroxaban would not be appropriate.

objective.__html: Manage symptomatic internal carotid artery disease.

references: Amarenco P. Transient ischemic attack. N Engl J Med. 2020;382:1933-1941.
